lines.content: Welcome to **Walkytalky**, your personal chatbot that helps you manage tasks efficiently!
Walkytalky supports three types of tasks:
- **Todo** `todo`– A simple task without a date/time.
- **Deadline** `deadline`– A task with a due date/time.
- **Event** `event`– A task with a start and end time.
Display all tasks in your task list:
- Walkytalky shows all tasks with their index numbers and status.
Marks the second task as completed.
Remove a task from your list:
Deletes the third task in the list.
Search for tasks containing a keyword:
Displays all tasks containing "meeting" in the description.
Walkytalky will show a goodbye message and save all tasks automatically.
- Commands are **case-insensitive**, e.g., `TODO` and `todo` are treated the same.
- Always use the correct command format to avoid errors.
- Walkytalky automatically saves all your tasks, so you don’t have to worry about losing data.

* Parses the user input into a specific Task, based on the command.

* Handles loading tasks from disk and saving tasks to disk.
* Tasks are stored in a plain text format and reconstructed at runtime.
* Constructs a Storage object for the given file path.
* @param filePath Path to the task file.
* Loads tasks from disk. If no file exists, an empty list is returned.

* Saves all tasks to disk, overwriting the file.
* @param tasks List of tasks to save.

* Represents a task with a description and completion status.
* Constructs a Task with the given description.
* Marks the task as not done.
* Returns the description of the task.
* Checks if the task is done.
* @return True if task is done, false otherwise.
* Returns a string representation of the task.
* Represents a list of tasks and provides operations to manage them,
* such as adding, deleting, searching, and listing tasks.
* Constructs a TaskList with existing tasks.
* Adds a task to the task list and displays a confirmation message.
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this task:");
System.out.println("Now you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in your list.");
* Deletes the task at the specified index.
* @param index Zero-based index of the task to delete.
* Retrieves the task at the specified index.
* @param index Zero-based index of the task.
* Returns all tasks in the list.
* Searches for tasks containing the given text in their description.
System.out.println("Sorry, I can't find such task.");
* Returns the number of tasks in the list.
* Prints all tasks with their indices and total count.
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
System.out.println("Now you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in your list.");
* Handles all user interaction for the Walkytalky application.
* Provides methods to display messages, read user commands,
* and show feedback for task operations.
* Constructs a new Ui object that reads input from standard input.
* Prints the welcome message and application logo to the user.
System.out.println(" Hi!!! I am your\n" + LOGO);
System.out.println(" You can ask me anything and I will always be here:)");
System.out.println(" What can I do for you today?");
* Displays an error message to the user, followed by a line divider.
* Reads a command entered by the user.
* @return Trimmed input string entered by the user.
* Prints the exit message when the user chooses to quit.
System.out.println("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!\n");
* Displays a confirmation message after marking a task as done.
* @param task Task that was marked as done.
System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
* Displays a confirmation message after unmarking a task.
* Displays a confirmation message after deleting a task.
* The main entry point for the Walkytalky application.
* Handles user interaction, command parsing, and task management.
* Constructs a Walkytalky instance, initializing storage, parser, UI, and task list.
* Continuously reads user input, parses commands, and executes them.
* Saves the task list after each valid operation.
